*Clarification about Unicode*
At 9:28 she is saying: "the most common version of unicode uses 16 bits with space for over a million codes" -- well, sixteen bits = 2^16=65.536. Yes, this was the size of the initial unicode, before it was expanded to "17 layers of 16bits" to include more characters; which then allows for 1 114 112 slots total. So I'm not sure if it's correct to say that Unicode is using 16 bits in that context... since it's actually 17*16bits.

Pretty sure we do not use true 32 bit color. We use r g b 8/8/8 in most cases, for 24 bit color. Some professional displays and apps use 10/10/10 for 30 bit color.

Some image encoding can have an 8 bit alpha channel for 8/8/8/8 or 32 bits, but there are others as well... 8/8/8/1 is good for simple masks. Obviously there can be more or less bits used for encoding, but most displays and games work with 24 bit color (8/8/8) as it can represent the colors r g b as 0-255, and luminance. 255 0 0 would be bright red, 128 0 0 would be red at half luminance...

Most devices have poor gamut though, and can only show 60-70% of those colors, but that's another thing.

I'm very late to the party, but I would like to clarify a few things. First, modern color bandwidth is 24 bits (3 bytes, 1 for each of red, green, and blue, which creates the RGB and HEX colour systems). Second, disambiguating "memory" and "storage" is important in this context; in this video, "memory" refers to hard drives (commonly called "storage"), sold in gigabytes or terabytes, to which "memory addresses" do not apply. Finally, the Unicode UTF-8 standard deserves its own video (of which it has many) and can encode 1 character to as little as 1 byte (ASCII-compatible) upto 32 bits (or 4 bytes).

the problem with unicode is the same as the problem of centralized planning, it won't catch all needs, and if it tries, will bloated, inefficient. the usual alternative of each language having it's own code is not much better, for there is much redundancy. there's a middle ground, where one makes a standardized encoding system, which lets anyone make their own character encoding, and anyone to easily install a new character encoding. though there is a concern raised that this would cause a flood of character encodings which would cause each computer to have a ton of encodings lest they are unable to decode some message, the fact is that people would gravitate, as a mediary between individuals, to local standard encodings which capture everything written in one script, perhaps with some small tweaks allowing similar scripts to be captured (the idea being to maximize how much content is encodable per the space all the content that is already, or will be in the foreseen future, encoded), while individuals might have their own preferred encoding on their private machine, if they are willing to host a transcoder between their code and the local standard.
the reason that this will happen is because
1: creators choosing to publish will want their work to be in a code their target understands, while creating in the code that is most effective for their work
2: consumers will want to use an code which most efficiently displays everything they consume
3: languages tend to be extremely different, though almost all, and i think all of which we are aware, though i do not claim to know all languages, so don't take my word for it, share many common features (Japanese (日本語) (i'm not a native usor of japanese, so if you know that something i wrote here is wrong, maybe you are a native usor of Japanese and have a differing opinion about your language, i won't be offended if you correct me, and will be delighted, because it will be an great opportunity for me to learn more), for instance, has many scripts, of of which there are usually only 3 that are used or mentioned (though it can be difficult to say whether a now mostly defunct script is a different script, or a historical variant of an existing script, or something else), 1 which is mostly semantic, called kanji (漢字 literally Sino-/Chinese Characters), in which most symbols have a meaning, and most symbol's can be analyzed into components, most of which of which also have meanings and are often used for their semantic properties, though sometimes for their phonetic properties, or even for their visual properties (take 口 which usually means (in the more abstract sense) mouth, derived from looking sorta like a mouth (e.g. 味, which means taste, or flavour, and 名 which means name (because when the crescent moon is the only source of light, it may be hard to see who you are speaking with, and thus must ask their name if you wish to identify them)), though in 石, meaning stone, it is used not to mean mouth but as a picture that looks like a big lump, or {\slant stone}, and in 團/団, meaning organization, it is just used to enclose 專/寸, and does not mean stone or mouth, and i think it has no specific semantic or phonetic interpretation, so it is encoded as a separate character, in english it is usually called the enclosure character), and words are ordered sequences of these kanji, and another 2 which are phonetic, called hiragana and katakana, which are also quite similar, but considered separate, and used differently. though all the scripts are still scripts written using strokes of a pen/pencil/brush on paper, just like English, and texts written in Japanese are still totally ordered strings of characters, just like English)

But seriously. Would have been nice to have a note on how ingenious the ASCII table is constructed which is more easily understood when indexed in binary.
A = 65 = 1000001
B = 66 = 1000010
...
a = 141 = 1100001
b = 142 = 1100010
Note how only the second bit differs between upper case and lower case letters. This means that holding down the shift button only had to flip one bit in the ASCII-code which made things a lot easier for designing keyboards as well as shifting text between upper/lower case or fixing all text to upper or lower case in software.
Same goes for numbers and the special characters on them
1 = 0110001
2 = 0110010
...
! = 0010001
2 = 0010010

Similarly holding down Ctrl flips the first bit which is why Ctrl-H on many systems can be used instead of backspace because H = 1001000 and [Backspace] = 0001000

Interesting aside, a byte is not guaranteed to be 8 bits. A byte is defined as:
"The smallest addressable unit of memory for a given architecture".

It just happens that we came to an agreement that for all modern computers this should be 8. Consequently if you happen to be reading network specifications you'll see the word "octet" rather than byte to be explicit about 8 bit bytes.
There is a mistake, a Byte is actually the smallest addressable unit in memory. The size 8 is just really common now.

Pixels are stored in 32 bits, but 8 of them are for the transparency channel, which is not used for photographs (although it can be used for filters on instagram, snapchat, photoshop etc). The other 24 bits are divided into 3 8-bit channels that can represent light intensity and color in many different ways, the most well-known being RGB (red/green/blue).

This video is really just a very big number. Take this number and pass it through the correct bit of software and it'll decode into the video that you are watching and listening to.

Here's how that works. As mentioned in the video, all data on a computer (including songs, images, and videos) are made up of a sequence of bits. Remember, too, that if you consider the sequence of bits to be in base 2, then that sequence is a number. Thus, if any sequence of bits is a number, and everything on a computer is made up of a sequence of bits, then everything on the computer can be thought of as just a number that is being interpreted to mean something else.

You can take this farther. The ENTIRE contents of your computer/phone/tablet can be represented by one single number. Send that number to somebody else, and they can reproduce your computer/phone/tablet EXACTLY with no differences at all. You gave them a number but they can see all of your files, photos, videos, passwords, settings... everything.

Oh, think of it like this -- the sum total of every video you have ever watched is also a single very (very) large number. Run that single number through a video decoder and voila, you are re-watching all of those videos again.

Gets done explaining Signed magnitude notation, then shows range for 2's complement notation... SMH. Fact check CRASH COURSE.

2's complement makes first big not the sign bit, but the negative value.

So in 8 bit, the 7th bit is -128, 6th bit is +64, 5th bit is +32, 4th is +16, 3rd is +8, 2nd bit is +4, 1st bit is +2, 0th bit is +1.

It's easy to spot the different in ranges.

In signed magnitude you'll go to +- the same ODD number. As a side effect you have + and - 0.

In 2's complement you go from a negative even number to a positive odd number. As such you don't have a + and - 0.

The fact the 32 bit number is negative even number to positive odd number is a dead giveaway it's 2's complement you actually showed.

-- Admittedly picky COMPUTER ENGINEER

Brief Pedantic correction:
Most Computers don't used Signed Numbers anymore, they use Two's Compliment. Its kind of the signed numbers Carrie Anne talks about but where your n'th digit represents its value but negative.
This means that -8 in a 4-bit notation would be 1000, -7 is 1001, -6 is 1010, etc. This allows for positive and negative numbers to be add together using simple addition without any complicated rules(so long as you don't get an overflow error).
Pedantic correction over.
